title: Pineapple Tallow Balm: My Weird Winter Skin Thing That Actually Worked
body:
So I’m sitting here, it’s dark by like 4:30, and my face feels like it’s made of old paper. You know that winter feeling. Everything is tight and itchy and just… angry. I was scrolling through Etsy one night, my foot was totally asleep, looking for a heavy-duty moisturizer that didn’t cost as much as my electric bill. Kept seeing this word. Tallow. Beef tallow balm. Specifically this one that said “Pineapple.” I clicked because, one, I was curious, and two, pineapple? With beef fat? My brain short-circuited for a second.

Anyway. I got it. I’ve been using this whipped tallow balm from some small shop for a few weeks now. The one that smells like a tropical vacation decided to hug a steak. I’m not a skincare person. I’m a “use whatever soap is in the shower” person. But this stuff? It’s weird. The good kind of weird. Let me back up.

## How Beef Fat Ended Up on My Bathroom Shelf

It started with my grandma, honestly. She’d always talk about “the old ways” of doing things. Rendering lard, using bag balm on everything. I’d roll my eyes. Then my skin freaked out this winter. Like, reptilian. I went down an internet rabbit hole at 11:47 PM, one beer in, and kept seeing people talk about **traditional tallow skincare**. Not as a new thing, but as a very, very old thing making a comeback.

Turns out, using animal fats on skin isn’t some weird TikTok trend. It’s ancient. Like, centuries ancient. Before fancy labs and chemical preservatives, people used what they had. Rendered fat from animals, often grass-fed beef suet, made into a balm. It makes a stupid amount of sense when you think about it. Our skin’s natural oil, sebum? It has a similar fatty acid profile to tallow. So it’s like giving your skin something it already recognizes. It just… absorbs. Doesn’t just sit on top like a greasy film. I read that and went, “Huh.” It was a slow Tuesday. I was already on Etsy. You see where this is going.

I was skeptical. Putting beef tallow on my face sounded like something you’d do on a dare. But the **natural skincare comeback** is full of this stuff—going back to simple, single-ingredient formulas. So I figured, worst case, I’d have a very expensive candle that smelled like a Hawaiian BBQ.

## What This Pineapple Tallow Balm Actually Does

The jar showed up. Cute packaging. Made in France, which felt fancy. I opened it. Texture was weird. Not bad weird. It’s whipped, so it’s super light and airy, but then you scoop some and it’s this dense, creamy… fat. Let’s just call it what it is. It feels rich. Not oily rich, like coconut oil. More like… the best hand cream you’ve ever stolen from a hotel, but better.

You warm it between your fingers. It melts. Then you put it on. And here’s the thing—it sinks in. Fast. My skin just drank it. No shiny residue. No feeling like I had to wipe my hands on my jeans. I used it on my Sahara-desert face first. Then my knuckles, which were cracking. Then my elbows, which are permanently rough.

The scent is what gets me. It’s called “Pineapple” and it’s this cheerful, sweet fruit smell. Not artificial candy pineapple. More like the memory of pineapple. Like if summer had a scent and it decided to be friendly. It’s not overpowering. It’s just… nice. Makes the whole experience feel less clinical and more like a treat. Which, in February, when the world is gray slush, is a big deal.

I started using it every night. After washing my face. Sometimes in the morning if I was feeling extra dry. It became my thing. My skin stopped feeling tight. The itchy patches on my cheeks? Gone. My lips, which are always chapped? I’d put a tiny bit on before bed. Woke up and they were just… normal lips. It was unsettling in the best way.

## My Skin After a Few Weeks of This Stuff

I don’t want to sound like an infomercial. But I looked in the mirror last week and my face just looked… calm. Not “glowing” or whatever. Calm. Hydrated. Like it wasn’t mad at me anymore. The fine lines around my eyes—the ones that look deeper when I’m dehydrated—seemed less obvious. Not gone. Just less shouty.

The biggest win was my hands. I wash them constantly. They were a disaster. Red, cracked, painful. I’d slather this tallow balm on at night, put on some cheap cotton gloves I found in a drawer, and sleep. After a few nights, the cracks started to heal. The skin felt softer. Not “baby soft” because that’s a creepy phrase. Just like my own skin again.

I even used it on a minor razor burn on my leg. Worked better than the special cream I bought. It’s just… versatile. I keep the jar on my nightstand. My boyfriend saw it, raised an eyebrow at the “beef tallow” part, tried it on his dry elbows, and now he steals it. So I guess I need to order another one.

It’s funny. We spend so much money on complex serums and creams with unpronounceable ingredients. And here’s this **beef tallow history** lesson sitting in a jar, working better than most of it. It’s humble. It’s simple. It’s literally one of the oldest skincare ingredients in the book. And my winter skin is thanking me for finally paying attention.

## Would I Buy This Pineapple Tallow Balm Again?

Yeah. I already did, actually. I’m on my second jar. I got one for my mom too, who has super sensitive skin and can’t use anything with fragrance. She was skeptical too (“You’re putting what on your face?”) but she called me last week to say her winter eczema patches were the calmest they’ve been in years. She didn’t even mind the pineapple smell.

I got mine from this little Etsy shop, Mt. Heritage. No, they’re not paying me. I just like what they made. It feels honest. Grass-fed beef, whipped into this balm, with just enough essential oil to make it smell like a vacation. That’s it. No fillers. No water. Just… the good stuff.

It’s not magic. It won’t turn back time. But if your skin is feeling stressed, dry, or just generally pissed off at the weather, it’s a solid thing to try. It’s the skincare equivalent of a warm, heavy blanket. Simple. Effective. Weirdly comforting.

Anyway. My coffee is getting cold. I just wanted to dump these thoughts somewhere because I kept telling my friends about this “weird beef balm” and they all asked for the link. So here it is, I guess. My little winter skin secret.

## Quick Questions I Get Asked

**Is beef tallow good for your face?**
Yeah, surprisingly. Because its fat profile is really close to our skin’s own sebum, it absorbs deeply and doesn’t just clog pores. It’s like giving your skin something it knows how to use. My face loves it, and my face is usually pretty fussy.

**Does tallow balm clog pores?**
Not in my experience. It feels heavy in the jar, but it melts and sinks right in. It’s non-comedogenic, which is a fancy way of saying it shouldn’t block pores. My skin feels moisturized, not greasy or congested.

**What does the Pineapple tallow balm smell like?**
It smells like pineapple, but not a Jolly Rancher. More like the idea of a ripe pineapple. Sweet, tropical, cheerful. It’s not super strong—it fades pretty quickly after you put it on—but it makes using it feel like a little treat, not a chore.

So yeah. If your skin is being difficult this season, might be worth a shot. It just works. I don’t know what else to say.
